metadata.title: Synthesis of porous carbon nano-onions derived from rice husk for high-performance supercapacitors

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Applied Surface Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/apsusc
Full length article
Synthesis of porous carbon nano-onions derived from rice husk for highperformance supercapacitors
Hong Jina,b,c, Shichao Wua,b,c, Ting Lia,b,c, Yilu Baia,b,c, Xiaolan Wanga,b,c, Hui Zhanga,b,c, Hui Xua,b,c,⁎, Chuncai Kongd,⁎⁎, Hongjie Wanga,⁎⁎
a State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behaviour of Materials, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710049, People's Republic of China b Xi'an Jiaotong University Suzhou Academy, Suzhou 215123, People's Republic of China c School of Nano-science and Nano-engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Suzhou 215123, People's Republic of China d School of Science, MOE Key Laboratory for Non-Equilibrium Synthesis and Modulation of Condensed Matter, State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an 710049, Shaanxi, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Supercapacitors Carbon nano-onions Rice husk Sustainable
A B S T R A C T
Porous carbon nano-onions (CNO) are prepared by a facile nickel assisted graphitization, followed by an activation procedure with renewable and sustainable rice husk as carbon precursor. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption results demonstrate that the CNO-700 possesses a porous structure and a high specific surface area of 3831 m2 g−1. The high graphitization degree and carbon-oxygen functional groups of CNO-700 have been characterized by X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, Transmission electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Further, the electrochemical properties are studied by galvanostatic charge/discharge, cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. CNO-700 shows a high specific capacitance of 350 F g−1 at the current density of 0.1 A g−1, good rate performance (288 F g−1 at 20 A g−1), and superior cycling performance with 99% of the capacitance retention over continuous 10,000 cycles at a current density of 20 A g−1 in the aqueous electrolyte of 6 M KOH. This suggests that the porous carbon nano-onions derived from rice husk is a promising electrode material for supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Electrochemical energy storage devices have received increasing attention due to their vast applications in electric vehicles and portable electronics [1–4]. Commercial electrochemical energy storage devices are mainly lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors (SCs) [5]. Compared with traditional lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors can be employed at high power density and maintain longer cycle life [6,7]. Based on their working principle, supercapacitors are generally divided into two types: electrical double-layer capacitors (EDLCs) and pseudocapacitors [8,9]. The energy storage of EDLCs is relying on the ions adsorption at the electrode/electrolyte interface, while the energy storage of pseudocapacitors is depending on fast and reversible faradaic redox reactions on the electrode surface. The relatively higher specific capacitance (above 1000F g−1) can be obtained by transition-metal oxides or conductive polymer-based pseudocapacitors than carbon based EDLCs [10–13]. However, the application of pseudocapacitors is
limited by the electrode materials which are intrinsically poor in electrical conductivity.
EDLCs present high commercial values for many applications due to the high rate-performance and cycle stability. Most of the electrodes for commercial supercapacitors are activated carbon materials on account of their high specific surface (over 2000 m2 g−1) and low cost [14,15]. However, traditional activated carbons consist of the amorphous carbon and large amounts of micro-pores of materials which lead to the high resistance of electron-transfer and ion-transfer. The performance of supercapacitors decays speedily as the current density increases to a high level [16,17]. Therefore, it is essential to find a proper carbon electrode material possessing better properties than traditional activated carbons. A great amount of attempts were made to investigate advanced carbonaceous materials [18–21]. The studies were mainly focused on two approaches. On the one hand, researchers endeavored to use high conductive carbonaceous materials such as carbon nanofibers, carbon nanotubes, fullerene, and graphene as alternative
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2019.05.308 Received 11 March 2019; Received in revised form 21 May 2019; Accepted 26 May 2019
⁎ Correspondence to: H. Xu, State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behaviour of Materials, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710049, People's Republic of China.
⁎⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: xhxuhui@xjtu.edu.cn (H. Xu), kongcc@xjtu.edu.cn (C. Kong), hjwang@xjtu.edu.cn (H. Wang).
Applied Surface Science 488 (2019) 593–599
Available online 28 May 2019 0169-4332/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
T
electrode for supercapacitors [22–24]. These carbonaceous materials can undoubtedly facilitate the electrode conductivity and promote the performance of SCs; nevertheless, the costs of these carbonaceous materials are much higher than traditional activated carbons. Some other researchers exerted inaugurate strategies on developing hierarchical graphitized porous carbon materials [25–28]. The proper porous structures can not only enhance the active sites for generating double layers, but also shorten ion diffusion distance [29]. Therefore, the porous graphitized carbon materials exhibit better high-rate performance than traditional activated carbon materials [30–32].
Inspired by these approaches, carbon nano-onion (CNO), an important member in carbon family, came into our mind. CNOs are also called as onion-like carbons, which are the promising electrode materials for high-performance supercapacitors by virtue of their innate properties [33]. The multiple graphitic outer shell structures facilitate the electron transport and the inner porous structures offer the double layer active sites [34]. The onion-like quasi-spherical with hollow-cage concentric graphene shells, were firstly reported in 1992 [35]. Since then, researchers tried different techniques, such as arc discharge, plasma, catalytic chemical vapor deposition and high temperature annealing of nano-diamond etc. to synthesize CNOs [36–38]. These methods are either expensive or limited scalability; moreover, the specific surface areas of the CNOs are merely around 500 m2 g−1, which is much less than ACs [39]. New approaches were developed to synthesize large-scale and low cost carbon nano onions [40]. Sustainable carbon precursors such as polymers, biomass, bio-wastes and polymers were utilized as the carbon sources for synthesizing CNOs [40].
Rice husk, which is also called as rice hull, is the protecting coating of rice [41]. It is used in the low value-added fields, such as insulation material, building material, paving material and fertilizer or even left in the field and burned after the rice harvest [42]. Rice husk consists of cellulose, hemicellulose, lignin and opaline silica [43]. The hard lignin and silica matrix are the protective and supportive components which protect the rice husk from collapsing [44]. As a renewable and sustainable carbon resource, rice husk has been investigated in synthesizing activated carbon materials for supercapacitors recently [45–49]. Although the high surface porous activated carbons have been obtained by the carbonization-activation process or the one-step carbonization method, which are the methods used to produce traditional activated carbon materials. The synthesis processes are in a high activation temperature, and the graphitization degree of the activated carbons is not high enough. Hence, it is essential to develop an effective approach for generating a porous graphitized carbon nano-onion via rice husk as the carbon source.
Here we slightly modified the traditional carbonization-activation method by adding nickel nitrate during the carbonization and labeled it as graphitization. The first step is the graphitization process. At a certain temperature, the lignocellulose decomposes into amorphous carbon and small molecules, while the nickel ions are reduced to nickel atoms within the matrix. Further, the nickel nanoparticles are surrounded by graphitized carbon layer, which is stable and thickening to inside [50,51]. The nickel crystals are then washed off by nitric acid. The second step is the chemical activation process, which is utilized to open up some of the graphitic shells and create hierarchical porous structures. The as-prepared carbons are utilized as the electrode
materials for supercapacitors to explore their electrochemical properties. The high specific capacitance of 350 F g−1 is obtained at a current density of 0.1 A g−1. And a high specific capacitance of 288 F g−1 can be maintained at a high current density of 20 A g−1 after 10,000 charge/discharge cycles. Which indicates the porous carbon nano-onion is an excellent candidate for high performance supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The rice husk, collected from a field near Lake Taihu, was washed with deionized water to remove dusts. Nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), ethanol, nitric acid (HNO3), polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE), and carbon black were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., and all chemicals were analytical grade. Membrane separator was donated from Celgard Co., Ltd. Deionized water was used as the solvent.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of porous CNOs
sections.text:
The first step is the graphitization process. The second step is the chemical activation process, which is utilized to open up some of the graphitic shells and create hierarchical porous structures. The route of our strategy is shown in Fig. 1.
The clean rice husk was dried in an oven at the temperature of 60 °C for 24 h. And then 10 g of dried rice husk (without grinding) was impregnated in 100mL (3.3 wt%) nickel nitrate solution and stirred for 12 h. The mixture was dried at 60 °C for 24 h and then moved to a tube furnace, and incubated at 600–800 °C for 1 h with the ramp of 10 °Cmin−1 under the protection of nitrogen gas. The carbonized mixture was washed with 2M nitric acid and then washed with deionized water until pH 7 and dried at 100 °C. The as-obtained black solids are denoted as RHG-600, RHG-700 and RHG-800 according to the graphitized temperature. The RHGs were immersed into potassium hydroxide solution (the mass ratio of RHG and KOH (3.0M) is 1:4) and dried overnight at 100 °C before loaded in a stainless steel container. The mixture was activated at 700 °C for 1 h in a tube furnace, and the as-obtained samples were washed with de-ionized water until pH=7. The resulting samples are denoted as CNO-600, CNO-700 and CNO-800 corresponding to RHGs.

sections.heading: 2.3. Characterization
sections.text:
Scanning electron microscopy (Phenom ProX) and the transmission electron microscopy (Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN) were used to characterize the morphology and microstructure of the as-prepared samples. The N2 adsorption/desorption isothermal technique (carried out at 77 K on the Autosorb IQ (Quantachrome Instruments)) was used to analyze BET surface area and pore size distribution. X-ray diffraction (XRD) (via D8 Advance of Bruker) was used to obtain the crystalline structure of the as-obtained samples. Raman spectrum (DXR 2xi (Thermo Fisher) with a 455 nm laser) was used to characterize the graphitization degree of the CNOs. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, AMICUS/ESCA 3400) was utilized to analyze the element composition and the surface
bonding state of the carbon materials.

sections.heading: 2.4. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
The supercapacitors preparation procedures were using our group's previous method [57]. Typically, a slurry containing 80wt% CNOs, 10 wt% carbon black and 10wt% PTFE binder was ground in a mortar and pestle to generate a homogeneous mixture. The mixture was then pressed onto a nickel foam with a pressure of 20MPa. Further, the electrodes were dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. The loading of the active materials in each supercapacitor electrode is around 3mg. The coin-type supercapacitors were assembled with two pieces of electrode separated by celgard-3501 membrane and 6M KOH as the electrolyte.
The complete CIMPS-4 system IM6 (Zahner) was utilized to characterize the cyclic voltammetry (CV) and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) results. The electrochemical impedance was conducted by a 5mV excitation signal in a frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz at the open circuit potential. Neware-CT-4008 (Neware, Shenzhen) was utilized to obtain the galvanostatic charge/ discharge data. According to the charge/discharge data, the specific capacitance of a single electrode can be calculated using Cs= 2It/mΔV, where Cs (F g−1) is the specific capacitance of one electrode, I is the charge or discharge current, t is the charge or discharge time, m is the active material mass in one electrode, and ΔV (we used a fixed voltage range from 0 to 1 V) is the voltage range during charge or discharge process.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
The properties such as surface area, pore size distribution of the carbon nano-onions are the crucial factors which affect the characteristics of the EDLCs. In this paper, the surface area and pore size distribution are characterized by the nitrogen adsorption/desorption via the Autosorb IQ. The isothermal curves, which are obtained from N2 adsorption/desorption techniques at 77 K, are used to calculate the surface areas and pore size distributions. As shown in Table 1, the surface area of these three CNOs is all higher than 1800 m2 g−1. The high surface areas of these samples are mainly created by the potassium hydroxide activation, which is like traditional chemical activation process (Firstly, carbon is corroded by potassium hydroxide to form porous structures 6KOH+2C→ 2 K+3H2+ 2K2CO3. And then K2CO3 decomposes to CO2, followed by the reaction of carbon and K/K2CO3/ CO2.). CNO-700 presents an extremely high surface area of 3831 m2 g−1 and a high pore volume of 2.89 cm3 g−1, which are higher than CNO-600 and CNO-800. Since the activation process of synthesizing CNO-700 is the same as the synthesizing procedure of CNO-600 and CNO-800. The highly porous structure of CNO-700 probably emanated from the properties of the RHG-700. The surface areas of the RHGs are characterized and the data is shown in table S1. The surface area of RHG-600 and RHG-700 are 258.1 and 275.1 m2 g−1. The raising of the RHG surface area can in fact provide more contact opportunities between RHG and potassium hydroxide. Therefore, CNO-700 obtains the higher surface area than CNO-600. While the surface area of RHG-800 is reduced to 251.6 m2 g−1, which is lower than the surface areas of RHG-600 and RHG-700.Therefore, the surface area of CNO-800 is the lowest among these CNOs.
The isothermal curves of CNOs are all presented hierarchical porous property as shown in Fig. 2a. In the small relative pressure (P/
P0≤ 0.05), all of these CNOs show microporous character. And in the P/P0between 0.05 and 0.5 all of them exhibit upward trend which is contributed by the small mesopores. For CNO-700 and CNO-800, the curves show a continuing increment in the P/P0between 0.5 and 0.99, which indicates the existence of large mesopores. The pore size distributions of the CNOs are shown in Fig. 2b, which shows a coincident result with the isothermal curves. All CNOs possesses several high microporous peaks, which are located at around 0.8–2.0 nm, and also a broad range of mesopores from 2.0 to 4.0 nm. While the pore size distribution curve of CNO-700 present a high peak at 4.8 and 5.2 nm, and a broad distribution to a high pore size of 10 nm. This demonstrates that CNO-700 has a hierarchically porous structure containing micropores for enhancing the charge storage and mesopores for mass transportation. The various pore size distributions of these CNOs are related to graphitization temperature. As shown in Fig. S1. With the graphitization temperature increasing from 600 °C to 800 °C, the peak intensity of the face-centered cubic phase nickel become stronger, and the fullwidth half-maximum of the (111) peak (2θ=44°) decreases slightly. According to Scherrer equation (D=Kλ/βcosθ, where D is the mean size of the ordered nickel particles, K is a constant value of 0.89, λ is the X-ray wavelength, β is the full-width at the half-maximum intensity, θ is the Bragg angle), the size of nickel nanoparticles increase as the graphitization temperature increases, and the data are shown in table S2. After removing the nickel nanoparticles, the different size pores are left on the carbon matrix. As a result, CNO-700 possesses a wider pore size distribution than CNO-600 as shown in Fig. 2b. The high temperature of 800 °C destroys more mesopore structures, therefore, more mesopore structures are maintained in CNO-700.
The XRD patterns of the CNOs are shown in Fig. 3a. It is obvious that the CNOs display one sharp peak at 2θ=26° and a weak peak at 44°, which are corresponding to the typical (002) and (101) reflections of graphitic carbons. Therefore, all CNOs synthesized by using nickel nitrate as a graphitization agent present the graphitic framework. As comparing the three samples, the diffraction peaks (002) of CNO-700 and CNO-800 are sharper than CNO-600. This implies that the highly graphitic crystalline structures can be created at the temperature as high as 700 °C.
To further assess the CNOs, Raman spectroscopy was used to characterize the CNOs, and the results are shown in Fig. 3b. The IG/ID value is used to evaluate the graphitization degree of a carbon sample [58]. IG represents the intensity of G band at around 1580 cm−1 due to the Carbon-Carbon sp2 hybridization in a hexagonal graphitic ring. While ID represents the intensity of D band at around 1350 cm−1 which originates from the vibration of the Carbon-Carbon sp3 hybridization and the disorder structure of the carbon sample [59]. And 2D band (at around 2700 cm−1) is the second-order two-phonon process, which is used to evaluate the layered graphene thickness [58]. As shown in Fig. 3b, the Raman spectroscopy of CNO-700 presents a distinct and sharp G-band at 1580 cm−1 and a small D band at 1350 cm−1. The IG/ ID value is 5.38, as shown in Table S3, which means CNO-700 is a highly graphitized carbon material. As the graphitization temperature increases to 800 °C, the IG/ID value of CNO-800 reaches to an even higher value of 16.78. The results demonstrate that the graphitization effect is in proportional to the graphitization temperature. CNO-600 shows a high D peak, and a negligible 2D peak. Which demonstrates that CNO-600 contains high amount of disordered carbon structures. CNO-800 has no D peak, and G peak is sharp and strong. It is probably due to the thick graphite layer formed during the 800 °C graphitization and the effective removal of the amorphous component during the following activation process. The Raman spectra results indicate that the graphitization-activation process can be used to synthesize a highly graphitized carbon material, and at the catalytic temperature of 700 °C, a few layer graphene similar structure carbon is produced.
Fig. 4a shows TEM image of RHG-Ni-700, which is the sample graphitized at 700 °C without acid wash. The nickel nanoparticle is encapsulated in the carbon matrix. In order to obtain a highly
graphitized porous carbon nano-onion material, the nickel nanoparticles and amorphous carbon structures are necessary to be removed. The nickel nanoparticles are facilely eliminated by acid washing. The XRD was used to determine whether the nickel nanoparticles are removed or not. As shown in Fig. S1b, the RHGs don't contain the crystal structure of nickel, which indicate the nickel nanoparticles can be purged away from the carbon materials. However, the broad peaks (Fig. S1b) at 20–30° indicate that the RHGs contain certain amount of amorphous carbon. Thus, the activation process is used to remove the amorphous carbon. The morphology and microstructures of the CNO-700 are shown in Fig. 4b–d. It can be seen from Fig. 4b that the CNO-700 maintains a three-dimensional macro-structure that is derived from rice husk. This is because of the high content of silica in rice husk which can be used to prevent the rice husk from collapsing during graphitization. And silica is transformed into silicate and located at the same place during the chemical activation. Therefore, the macro-matrix of the rice husk can't be heavily destroyed in the procedure. The micro-porous foam-like structures are formed in the procedure just as shown in Fig. 4b. This can be explained by the normal activation regularity. During the activation process, the carbon materials react with potassium hydroxide and create porous structures. The highly interconnected property in the nanoscale is also detected by TEM as shown in Fig. 4c. And the onion-like open pore structure can be seen in Fig. 4d. While the edge of the onion is mostly graphite layers. From the high resolution TEM image (Fig. 4d), it can be seen that the walls of the onion layers are somehow expended. And the nano-porous structures in the graphitic layers indicate that the graphitized carbon shells are corroded by potassium hydroxide as well.
XPS was performed to further identify the elemental information and carbon bonding state of the CNO-700. The wide scan spectrum of CNO-700 (Fig. 5a) shows a C 1s peak at around 284 eV and an O 1s peak at about 532 eV. This demonstrates that the CNO-700 is mainly composed of carbon and oxygen elements. In order to go deep into the carbon bonding state, the high resolution XPS scan of C 1s was
employed and the result is shown in Fig. 5b. There are five peaks at 284.5, 285.4, 286.5, 287.8 and 288.9 eV which correspond to graphitized carbon C]C, defect carbon or CeC in aromatic rings, C]O, CeO, O=C-O, respectively. The results indicate that CNO-700 is composed of defective graphitized carbon and oxygenated functional groups. The graphitized carbon structure promotes the electrical conductivity and the functional groups are favorable for the adsorption of the electrolyte.
The high specific surface area and three-dimensional hierarchical porous structures are the favorable characteristics of CNOs. These characteristics are also considered as the most crucial factors for high performance supercapacitors. In order to investigate the electrochemical properties of CNOs, the coin-type two electrodes supercapacitors were assembled. The electrodes were prepared by conventional methods, and each of the CNOs materials was mixed with conductive carbon black and polytetrafluoroethylene in a ratio of 8:1:1. The mixture was pressed on a nickel foam and 6M KOH aqueous solution was used as the aqueous electrolyte to prepare button-type supercapacitors.
The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy technique was used to study the overall kinetics of the as-prepared electrodes [60]. As shown in Fig. 6a, an extremely low charge transfer resistance of around 0.05Ω (diameter of the semicircle) can be clearly found in the high frequency region compared with CNO-600 and CNO-800 (Fig. S3). And the linear part in the low frequency region, which is almost perpendicular to abscissa axis, is comparable to ideal double layer capacitors. Such small charge transfer resistance and ideal linear region are intimately related to the unique property of the carbon sample. Since CNO-700 is a hierarchically porous graphitic carbon, it can provide a high conductivity and rich open pore structures, which facilities the high electron and ion transportation. The cyclic voltammetry curves are shown in Figs. 6b and S4. The superb rectangular curves at the scanning rate of 200mV s−1. Even at the ultra-high scanning rate of 1000mV s−1, the CV curve has changed but still maintained a shape close to a rectangle as shown in Fig. S5, which demonstrated that an ideal capacitor

It is clear that the pore volume of CNO-700 is much larger thanCNO-600 and CNO-800. (b) Pore size distribution of the CNOs. The pore size distribution was analyzed by nonlinear density functional theory (NLDFT). It confirms that CNO-700 presents a wider size distribution profile than the other two CNOs.
behavior and high-rate performance can be achieved by CNO-700. Galvanostatic charge-discharge technique was used to investigate the rate capability and cycle stability. The specific capacitances at the current density ranging from 0.1 A g−1 to 20 A g−1 are shown in Fig. 6c. CNO-700 exhibits a high specific capacitance of 350 F g−1 at 0.1 A g−1 and 288 F g−1 at 20 A g−1 indicating a high capacity maintain. CNO-700 showed superior specific capacitance compared to already reported carbon-based materials as show in Table 2.
Galvanostatic charge/discharge curves of CNO-700 are shown in Fig. 6d and the single-electrode galvanostatic charge/discharge curves were tested by an aqueous three-electrode setup are shown in Fig. S6, and the symmetric triangular profiles through a large range of current density indicate its high energy storage efficiency. Specifically, the triangle profile at 10 A g−1 was highlighted and shown in Fig. 6e. It has no obvious voltage drop in this high current density indicating an extremely small internal resistance. As a result of this, the cycle
performance at the current density of 20 A g−1, as shown in Fig. 6f, is extremely stable. It was found that CNO-700 still maintained its open pore structure and few graphite layers after 10,000 cycles, as shown in Fig. S7(a) and (b).

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
CNOs from rice husk have been synthesized via a facile combination
of graphitization and activation process. The CNOs exhibit an outstanding electrochemical performance, which is achieved by the extremely high surface area, the modest carbon oxygen functional groups, and the 3D micro-open porous graphitic structures. These features facilitate a sufficient space for ion storage, hierarchical porous channels for ion transfer and high conductivity carbon matrix for electron transfer. The high specific capacitance of 350 F g−1 (0.1 A g−1) was achieved based on CNO-700, and a high specific capacitance of 288 F g−1 was maintained even at a high current density of 20 A g−1. Meanwhile, it also presented an extremely good cycling stability since there is almost no attenuation after 10,000 cycles at 20 A g−1. In summary, this study indicates that the value-added carbon materials can be synthesized through a facile procedure based on bio-wastes such as rice husk.

referenceMentions.context: Commercial electrochemical energy storage devices are mainly lithium-ion batteries and supercapacitors (SCs) [5].
Compared with traditional lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors can be employed at high power density and maintain longer cycle life [6,7].

metadata.abstractText: Porous carbon nano-onions (CNO) are prepared by a facile nickel assisted graphitization, followed by an activation procedure with renewable and sustainable rice husk as carbon precursor. The nitrogen adsorption/desorption results demonstrate that the CNO-700 possesses a porous structure and a high specific surface area of 3831 m g. The high graphitization degree and carbon-oxygen functional groups of CNO-700 have been characterized by X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, Transmission electron microscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Further, the electrochemical properties are studied by galvanostatic charge/discharge, cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. CNO-700 shows a high specific capacitance of 350 F g at the current density of 0.1 A g, good rate performance (288 F g at 20 A g), and superior cycling performance with 99% of the capacitance retention over continuous 10,000 cycles at a current density of 20 A g in the aqueous electrolyte of 6 M KOH. This suggests that the porous carbon nano-onions derived from rice husk is a promising electrode material for supercapacitors.
